Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story: The clock on my desk blinked 4:45 PM—just over an hour left before the quarter closed. My sales manager’s voice echoed in my head: “We need three more sign-ups, or we all lose our bonuses.” My fingers hovered over the phone, the script open in front of me. I knew which leads were most likely to say yes—elderly folks who’d picked up before, confused but polite. The pressure was suffocating. I thought of the Bible verse I’d read that morning: “Do to others as you would have them do to you.” My Christian faith told me to be honest, to treat people with respect, not to manipulate or pressure. But the numbers on the screen, the threat of letting my team down, the fear of missing rent—they all screamed at me to push harder, to gloss over the fine print, to close the deal no matter what. My hand trembled as I dialed the next number, my heart pounding with the weight of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
